question_stem: The function \(g(x)\) is defined for all real values of \(x\). The graph of \(y = g(x)\) passes through the points (1, 2), (4, 5) and (7, -1).

parts.question_text: Write down three points that lie on the graph of \(y = g(x-2)\).
parts.solution_text:
The transformation \(y = g(x-2)\) represents a horizontal translation of the graph \(y=g(x)\) 2 units to the right.
So, we add 2 to the x-coordinate of each given point.
(1, 2) becomes (1+2, 2) = (3, 2)
(4, 5) becomes (4+2, 5) = (6, 5)
(7, -1) becomes (7+2, -1) = (9, -1)
Therefore, the three points on the graph of \(y = g(x-2)\) are (3, 2), (6, 5) and (9, -1).
